bibl.title: Letter from Edward R. Stitt to Henry Rose Carter, October 27, 1924

div1.p: Stitt writes that no serious attempt was made at the Naval Medical School to discover a satisfactory repellent for mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Edward R. Stitt to Henry Rose Carter, October 27, 1924
div1.opener:
DEPARTMENT OF THE NAVY
BUREAU OF MEDICINE & SURGERY
DO NOT ADDRESS THE SIGNER OF THIS LETTER
BUT ADDRESS YOUR REPLY TO
BUREAU OF MEDICINE AND SURGERY
NAVY DEPARTMENT, WASHINGTON, D. C.,
JRP-LMA
AND REFER TO NO. SD-132695-0
(104)
WASHINGTON, D. C. October 27, 1924.
Dear Doctor Carter:-
div1.p:
According to our records no serious attempt was made at
the Naval Medical School to discover a satisfactory repellant
for mosquitoes.

Doctor A.H. Allen of the Navy, while attached to the
Philadelphia Navy Yard, took up the question with Professor
Hirschfelder of the University of Minnesota and with the Bureau
of Medicine and Surgery, but so far as we know a satisfactory
repellant was not discovered.

At the Philadelphia Yard, as you probably know, they have
to deal with a bad mosquito pest - Culex and Aedes solicitans.
There is a permanent antimosquito board at the Navy Yard to
consider ways and means of combating mosquitoes in the Yard
and to cooperate with civilian agencies on the Pennsylvania
side of the river and so far as practicable to secure coopera-
tion across the river in New Jersey.

I am sorry that we are unable to make any suggestion that
will be of value to you in considering the problem of the
United Fruit Company.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, E.R. Stitt,
Surgeon General, U.S. Navy. send to Deeks
Le Prince says
Assistant Surgeon General
H.R. Carter, U.S. Public Health Service,
2122 California Street, N.W.,
Washington,. D.C.
